title: Crested Gecko Enclosure Setup Guide: Complete Housing Requirements
description: Complete enclosure setup guide for crested geckos covering dimensions, materials, vertical layout design, equipment checklist, and arboreal habitat creation.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Essential Housing for Crested Geckos
content.content: Crested geckos are arboreal (tree-dwelling) lizards from the tropical rainforests of New Caledonia. Creating an appropriate vertical habitat with climbing opportunities, proper temperature gradients, and humidity management is essential for their health and wellbeing. This guide covers everything you need to know about setting up the perfect crested gecko enclosure.
Crested geckos are arboreal and need enclosures that are taller than they are wide. Height allows for natural climbing behaviors and creates a temperature gradient from warm (top) to cool (bottom).

content.text: Minimum Enclosure Sizes:

rows: Temporary grow-out enclosure for easy feeding/monitoring
Minimum for proper thermoregulation and exercise
More climbing space improves enrichment and activity

content.content: Young crested geckos under 12g benefit from smaller grow-out enclosures where they can easily locate food and navigate safely. Move to adult-sized housing once they reach 12-15g and demonstrate confident climbing.
Different enclosure materials offer unique advantages for crested gecko keeping. Consider humidity retention, ventilation, viewing access, and durability.

content.text: Material Options:

rows: Not recommended - humidity too difficult to maintain
Advanced keepers, bioactive setups, maximum humidity control

content.content: Front-opening glass terrariums are ideal for crested geckos. Top-opening enclosures can stress arboreal species that perceive threats from above (like birds in the wild).

For complete guidance on creating vertical thermal gradients and selecting temperature monitoring equipment, see our Understanding Thermal Gradients and Temperature Monitoring Equipment guides. Crested geckos require a vertical gradient with basking at the top (82-85°F) and cooler zones at the bottom (70-75°F).
While crested geckos are arboreal, substrate serves critical functions: humidity retention, cushioning falls, and supporting live plants in bioactive setups.

content.text: Substrate Options (2-4" depth):

rows: DIY Tropical Mix (60% topsoil + 40% coco fiber)
Natural appearance, foraging enrichment, CUC habitat

content.content: Avoid paper towels, reptile carpet, or sand. These don't retain humidity adequately and paper products can stick to gecko feet. Add generous leaf litter on top of substrate for naturalistic appearance.
Décor is not optional—it's essential for crested gecko mental and physical health. Create a dense, jungle-like environment with multiple pathways.

content.text: Climbing Enrichment Items:

rows: Diagonal from bottom to top, intersecting for pathways
Vertical and horizontal, create highway system
Weave through branches, connect all vertical zones
Dense foliage at top (cover) and mid-levels (security)
Mid to upper level, easily accessible from vines
Upper level near basking zone for daytime sleep
Draped over branches, increases humidity and cover

content.content: Aim for 70-80% coverage with plants and vines. Crested geckos feel most secure in densely planted environments. If you can see the back wall easily, add more foliage.

content.text: Day-by-Day Setup Process:

rows: Install lights, heat lamp, thermometers. Test all equipment without gecko.
Add substrate (2-4"), position branches/cork bark, secure with substrate.
Install live plants (if using), arrange artificial plants, weave vines through hardscape.
Run setup for 48 hours. Verify basking temp 82-85°F, humidity 60-80%.
Install magnetic ledges, place feeding cups, add water features if applicable.
Place gecko in enclosure during evening hours (their active time). Monitor for 24-48 hours.

content.text: Mistakes to Avoid:

rows: Use glass terrarium with screen top only
Stress, refusal to eat, hiding constantly
Heat lamp at top only, cool zone at bottom
Choose front-opening or add front access
Can't find food, stress from exposure
Gecko tries to escape through glass
Add foam background or dense plants on back wall

content.content: Cohabitation is controversial and generally not recommended for novice keepers. Crested geckos can be housed together but require specific conditions.

content.text: Cohabitation Guidelines:

rows: Size difference, competition for basking, food aggression
Breeding stress, male aggression, dominance issues
Severe fighting, injuries, tail loss, death

content.content: Males should NEVER be housed together—they will fight and cause severe injuries. If attempting cohabitation with females, provide multiple feeding stations, hides, and basking areas to reduce competition. Monitor daily for signs of stress or aggression (tail loss, bite marks, weight loss, one gecko always hiding).

For first-time crested gecko keepers, house your gecko individually. Cohabitation adds complexity, risk, and requires larger enclosures with redundant equipment—factors that increase difficulty significantly.
